msContents.summary: This manuscript includes a Pañcarakṣā collection and a Saptavāra collection. The Pañcarakṣā "Five Protections" consists of the Mahāpratisarā, Mahāmāyūrī, Mahāsāhasrapramardanī, Mahāmantrānusāriṇī, and Mahāśītavatī (in various sequences). The earliest evidence for texts grouped together as the "Five Great Dhāraṇīs" comes from Tibetan catalogues around 800 CE, but this compendium is somewhat different from the surviving Sanskrit collection, which is preserved in manuscripts dating back to the eleventh century. These scriptures include spells, enumerations of benefits and ritual instructions for use. With the course of time all of them became deified and five related goddesses emerged. It is, however, important to note that the texts themselves do not have any references to these goddesses. The Saptavāra ("Seven Days") usually incorporates seven dhāraṇīs, the Vasudhārā, Vajravidāraṇā, Gaṇapatihṛdayā, Uṣṇīṣavijayā, Parṇaśavarī/Prajñāpāramitā, Mārīcī, and Grahamātṛkā. This collection associates each dhāraṇī with a specific day of the week, a tradition going back to at least the sixteenth century in Nepal. This paper manuscript, probably to be ascribed to the 17th or 18th century, is illuminated with miniatures of the various goddesses, represented at the beginning of each dhāraṇī. The original wood cover bears traces of ritual worship. Instead of the Vasudhārā, the Saptavāra contained in this manuscript begins with the Vasudhārānāmāṣṭottaraśataka (although the final rubric mistakenly identifies it as a Vasudhārādhāraṇī). The manuscript is incomplete as it misses the last folio, which contained the end of the colophon.

msItem.title: Pañcarakṣā
msItem.incipit: [1v1] evam mayā śrutam ekasmin samaye bhagavā[1v2]n_ vajrameruśikharakūṭāgāre viharati [miniature] sma ḥ || tad idāni pravakṣāmi bhūtasaṃghā śṛṇo[1v3]ntu me namo buddhāya || namo dharmmāya || namo saṃghā[miniature]ya ḥ || namaḥ sarvatathāgatānāṃ namo namaḥ || sarvva[1v4]buddhabodhisatvādharmmasaṃghebhyaḥ ||
msItem.explicit: [14v1] yāniha bhūtāni samāgatāni sthitāni bhūmāv athavāntarīkṣe kurvantu maitrī satataṃ prajāsu divā [14v2] ca rātrau ca carantu dharmmaṃ || @ || iti tatra buddhānāṃ buddhānubhāvena, devatānā devatānubhāvena, mahati vyupaśānteti ||
msItem.finalRubric: [14v3] āryamahāpratiśarā, āryamahāsāhasra[14v4]prarmardanī, āryamahāmāyurī, āryamahāśitavatī, āryamahāmantrānusāraṇi samāpta || @ ||
msItem.colophon: [14v3] ye dharmā hetuprabhavā [14v4] hetu teṣāṃ tathāgato,,hy avadat teṣāñ ca yo nirodha, evaṃvādī mahāśramaṇaṃ ḥ || @ || śubhamaṅgalaṃ bhavantu || @ ||

msItem.title: Saptavāra
msItem.incipit: [15r] di[miniature]vyarūpi surūpī ca,, saumyarūpidharapraḍā vasudharī [15r2] vasumbārīś ca, vasuśrī śrīkarī varā,, dharaṇī dhāra[miniature]ṇī dhātā śaraṇya bhaktivasalā,, prajñāpāramitāde[15r3]vi, prajñā śrīburddhavarddhanī,|
msItem.rubric: [18r4] $ oṃ namo bhagavatyai āryyavajavidārīṇai || namo buddhāya ||
msItem.finalRubric: [20v1] iti vajavidāruṇā nāma dhāraṇī, hṛdayāpa[miniature]hṛdayaḥṃ mūrasūtraṃ samāptaḥ || @ ||
msItem.rubric: [25r3] $ oṃ namo bhagavatyai āryaparṇṇasavarītārāyai ḥ || [miniature] namo ratnatrayāya ḥ ||
msItem.finalRubric: [28r1] || @ || āryamā[28r2]rici nāma dhālaṇī samāptam iti riya bhavati [miniature] || @ ||
msItem.explicit: [34v2] idam avocad bhagavāṃn āttamanās tte ca bhikṣavo,, bodhisattvā sā ca [34v3] savāvatiprarṣa sadevamānuṣāsuragarudagandharvvaś ca loko bhagavato bhāṣītam abhyandandan iti || ^^^||
msItem.colophon: [34v5] ye dharmmā hetuprabhāvā hetu teṣāṃ tathāgato hy avadat teṣāñ ca yo nirodha evaṃvādī ma¦

supportDesc.foliation: Nepālākṣarā letter-numerals, mid-left margin, verso (only on folios 1-14 and 16-17).
supportDesc.condition: Incomplete, in good condition. Many folios look dirty or stained. The writing is sometimes faded.

layout.p: 5 lines per page, approximately 45 akṣaras per line.

decoNote.desc:
The beginnings of the various dhāraṇis are decorated with (sometimes damaged) polichrome miniatures of approximately 4.5 cm in width, drawn in the centre of the page:
On f. 1v, representation of the goddess Pratisarā.
On f. 6r, representation of the goddess Sāhasrapramardanī.
On f. 7v, representation of the goddess Māyūrī.
On f. 11r, representation the goddess Śītavatī.
On f. 13r, representation the goddess Mantrānusāriṇī.
On f. 15r, representation the goddess Vasudhārā.
On f. 18v, representation the goddess Vajravidāraṇā.
On f. 20v, representation of the goddess Ganapatihṛdayā.
On f. 22r, representation of the goddess Uṣṇīṣavijayā.
On f. 25r, representation of the goddess Parṇaśavarī.
On f. 26v, representation the goddess Mārīcī.
On f. 28r, representation the goddess Grahamātṛkā.

list.item: On the inner side of the back cover, a note on a paper slip, attached to the cover, bearing the number of folios.

item.marginalia:
The beginnings of the various dhāraṇis bear vertical writings on the left margin with their names, in the case of the Pañcarakṣā, or with the names of the week days related to the respective texts, in the case of the Saptavāra:
[1v] $ pratisarāyā ||
[6r] $ sāhasrapamardani
[7v] $ māyūriyā ||
[11r] $ śitavatiyā ||
[13r] $ mantrānusādhaniyā ||
[15r] $ ādityayā ||
[18r] $ somavālayā ||
[20v] $ maṅgaravālayā ||
[22r] $ budhavārayā ||
[25r] $ bṛhaspatiyā ||
[26v] $ śuklayā ||
[22v] $ śaniścarayā ||

decoNote.desc: On the outer side of the front cover, traces of materials smeared on the manuscript during worship rites.

history.provenance:
Presented by Mrs. E.K. Waterhouse Waterhouse, E. K.
in 1957.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions).
